person.persName: Thomas B. Monroe, Sr. (Provisional Congress of the Confederate States)

body.p: A Virginia-born attorney and politician. Family moved to Scott County, Kentucky circa 1793 and, upon reaching adulthood, he settled in Barren County. Served as a member of the Kentucky House of Representatives in 1816. Studied law and began law practice. Moved to Frankfort, Kentucky. Graduated from the law department of Transylvania University in 1821. Married to Eliza Palmer Adair Monroe. Father of Victor Monroe, Katherine “Kitty” Adair Monroe, Polly/Mary Hardin Monroe, Elizabeth Adair Monroe Leovy, Thomas Bell Monroe, Jr., Benjamin James Monroe, and William W. Monroe. Owned three enslaved persons in 1850. Served as Kentucky Secretary of State from 1823 to 1824. Served as reporter for the Kentucky Court of Appeals in 1825. Served as U.S. District Attorney for the District of Kentucky from 1831 to 1834. Served as U.S. District Judge for the District of Kentucky from 1834 until 1861. Engaged as professor of law for the University of Louisiana, Transylvania University, and the Western Military Academy. Taught private law classes at his Frankfort, Kentucky estate—Montrose. Served as a member of the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States from 1861 to 1862. Lived as a refugee throughout the South from 1861 to 1865, living in Canton, Mississippi; Marietta Georgia; Abbeville, South Carolina; and Pass Christian, Mississippi. Died on December 23, 1865 in Pass Christian, Mississippi.
